G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable), which authorize the Probate and Family Court to make and modify orders relative to the custody, visitation, and support of minor children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20 (as applicable).proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable), which authorize the Probate and Family Court to make and modify orders relative to the custody, visitation, and support of minor children.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: Massachusetts is the minor child’s “home state” within the meaning of the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, § 2, and the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction provisions, and this Court has jurisdiction to modify its prior custody and parenting‑time order.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the Original Judgment was issued by this Court and the minor child has resided in Middlesex County during the relevant period.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 34.proposition: To the extent necessary, Mother requests a temporary order pending final hearing, modifying parenting time to remove the midweek overnight if and when Father relocates to New Hampshire or to any other location that causes similarly burdensome travel for Emily on school nights, so as to prevent ongoing harm and disruption to her schooling and routines.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Since entry of the Existing Order on April 15, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances within the meaning of Massachusetts law.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts standard for modification of alimony or child support: the moving party must show a material change in circumstances since entry of the earlier judgment. Although the court ultimately finds no such change on the facts presented, Schuler is clear authority on the legal requirement that a material and substantial change in circumstances is needed under Massachusetts law, which is what the proposition asserts in general terms (not fact-specific to this case).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Since entry of the Existing Order on April 15, 2021, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances within the meaning of Massachusetts law.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts standards for modification based on a material and substantial change in circumstances after an existing order (such as a custody or support order). Smith v. McDonald deals with statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the improper use of the Yannas ‘removal’ analysis, not with post‑judgment modification or the ‘material and substantial change’ standard. The opinion therefore does not address, establish, or apply the change‑in‑circumstances requirement and cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’... I concur that the judgment must be vacated and the case remanded to the Probate and Family Court for further proceedings as to custody and visitation..."

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: As a result of the anticipated relocation and the new distance between the parties’ homes, the parenting‑time schedule that was appropriate and workable in 2021 has become impracticable, unduly burdensome, and contrary to the minor child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns a removal request where the custodial parent is allowed to relocate the children from Massachusetts to Greece and a new long‑distance parenting schedule is created. The court does not characterize the prior in‑state parenting arrangement as impracticable or unduly burdensome due to distance; instead, it accepts that visitation will be significantly altered but holds that this disadvantage cannot be controlling if removal is otherwise in the children’s best interests. Thus, it does not support the proposition that relocation has rendered the prior schedule impracticable or contrary to the child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The reasonableness of alternative visitation arrangements should be assessed. The fact that visitation by the noncustodial parent will be changed to his or her disadvantage cannot be controlling. … Certainly the move to Greece would be to the advantage of the wife, financially, emotionally, and socially. The children should benefit from that advantage… Additionally, the husband has large blocks of free time, and travels to Greece often. The children can visit this country every year.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: As a result of the anticipated relocation and the new distance between the parties’ homes, the parenting‑time schedule that was appropriate and workable in 2021 has become impracticable, unduly burdensome, and contrary to the minor child’s best interests.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition claims that increased distance from a relocation rendered an existing parenting-time schedule impracticable and not in the child’s best interests. Rosenthal v. Maney involves a proposed relocation from Northborough, MA to Providence, RI (about 55 miles), but the Appeals Court emphasizes that such a distance would not significantly impair visitation and reverses the lower court’s refusal to allow the move. The opinion therefore rejects, rather than endorses, the idea that the new distance made the prior schedule unduly burdensome or contrary to the child’s best interests.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “In light of the fact that the distance between Northborough and Providence is but fifty-five miles and has not precluded significant access to both parents, it is likely that by living in Providence the effect on Caleb’s association with the father would be no greater than the effect on the child’s association with the mother if he were to remain in Northborough. … There is nothing in the evidence to suggest that a relocation to Providence… would preclude the father… from having contact with Caleb in a manner significantly different from that provided by the original divorce judgment.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting‑time order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint custody context and repeatedly frames the standard as whether removal is in the children’s best interests. It does not articulate or apply the familiar two‑part modification standard requiring a threshold showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests. The only reference to ‘substantial change in circumstances’ is in a quoted ALI provision about relocation, not as Massachusetts’ governing rule for custody or parenting‑time modifications generally.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u20.relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] …

“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests …”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a party seeking modification of a custody or parenting‑time order must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the distinction between initial custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) (using a ‘best interests of the child’ standard) and modification proceedings under G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (requiring a ‘substantial change in the circumstances’). However, the Court expressly declines to apply or elaborate on the modification standard and resolves the case as an initial custody determination. It therefore does not clearly establish the two‑part test for modification orders stated in the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 842\u201.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … General Laws c. 209C, § 20, gives the Probate Court jurisdiction to modify an existing judgment for support, custody, or visitation. Such a modification should be made only if ‘a substantial change in the circumstances of the parties or the child has occurred.’”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Father’s relocation out of state, combined with the substantial increase in travel time for Emily during school nights and the related interference with her schooling and activities, constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde v. Rolde does not address parental relocation, out-of-state moves, or travel time effects on a child’s schooling or activities. The case concerns division of marital assets, custody (including joint vs. sole custody), and visitation, but there is no discussion of relocation as a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, it does not support the specific relocation-based proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt:
We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge “cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.” There is no error.

From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Continuation of the midweek overnight parenting‑time schedule in the context of Father’s substantial relocation would no longer serve Emily’s best interests and is likely to be detrimental to her emotional well‑being, educational development, and overall stability.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The case concerns custody determinations in the context of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about the effect of such violence on a child’s best interests. It does not address parental relocation, midweek or overnight parenting schedules, or how a move affects a child’s emotional well‑being, education, or stability. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about discontinuing a midweek overnight schedule after a substantial relocation.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.proposition: Continuation of the midweek overnight parenting‑time schedule in the context of Father’s substantial relocation would no longer serve Emily’s best interests and is likely to be detrimental to her emotional well‑being, educational development, and overall stability.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.support_reasoning: The case concerns a care-and-protection proceeding where the State sought to remove a newborn from the mother due to parental unfitness and chronic neglect. It addresses standards for state intervention, parental unfitness, and evidentiary requirements, not parenting-time schedules, relocation, or the impact of midweek overnights on a child’s best interests, emotional well‑being, education, or stability. Thus it does not provide authority for modifying or discontinuing a midweek overnight schedule after a parent’s relocation.
Custody of a Minor (No. 1), 377 Mass. 87.relevant_excerpt: Because the interest of the child is thought to be best served in the stable, continuous environment of his own family... State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.... The court need not wait until it is presented with the maltreated child before it decides the necessity of “care and protection.” Rather, an assessment of prognostic evidence derived from an ongoing pattern of parental neglect or misconduct is appropriate in the determination of future fitness and the likelihood of harm to the child.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts emphasize that the “best interests of the child” standard is the paramount consideration in matters affecting custody and parenting time.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the central issue, once parental unfitness is found, as determining what is in the child’s best interests and treats that standard as controlling in resolving the custody/adoption placement dispute. The court repeatedly describes the trial judge’s task under G.L. c. 210, § 3 as choosing the placement that serves the child’s best interests and defers to his discretionary application of that standard, confirming it as the paramount consideration in such custody/parenting-time type decisions.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Mother does not seek to interfere with or diminish the quality of Emily’s relationship with Father; rather, she seeks a parenting‑time structure that is realistic, sustainable, and truly in Emily’s best interests in light of Father’s decision to relocate.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenberg v. Merida concerns child support calculation with Social Security disability benefits, attachment of assets, and the standard for modifying legal custody. It does not involve parental relocation, parenting-time structure, or a parent’s intent (or lack of intent) to interfere with the child’s relationship with the other parent. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition about the mother’s motives regarding father–child contact or the appropriateness of a revised parenting-time schedule after relocation.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding “that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].” The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.

Nystrom v. Nystrom, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 10.raw_text: Nystrom v. Nystrom, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 1018 (1982)
Nystrom v. Nystrom, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 10.proposition: Courts in Massachusetts have recognized that substantial changes in a parent’s residence, employment, or schedule—when they significantly affect the child’s routine—may justify modification of parenting time to protect the child’s best interests.
Nystrom v. Nystrom, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 10.support_reasoning: The case is a tort/personal injury and workers’ compensation/special employee dispute arising from a construction-site accident. It does not involve family law, child custody, or modification of parenting time, nor does it discuss changes in a parent’s residence, employment, schedule, or the best interests of a child. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the parenting-time modification proposition claimed.
Nystrom v. Nystrom, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 10.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff, an employee of Palmer Paving Corp. (Palmer), brought this action to recover damages for injuries he sustained in an accident at a construction site on October 25,1978, allegedly caused by the negligence of the defendants Roger W. Boas (Boas) and Boas’ employer, Ben Moccio & Sons Excavating Co. (Moccio). ... 1. The defendants claim error in the denial of their motion for a directed verdict on the ground that the evidence required a finding that Boas, the driver of a truck owned by Moccio, was, at the time of the accident, a special employee of Palmer.

Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635 (1999).proposition: To the extent necessary, Mother requests a temporary order pending final hearing, modifying parenting time to remove the midweek overnight if and when Father relocates to New Hampshire or to any other location that causes similarly burdensome travel for Emily on school nights, so as to prevent ongoing harm and disruption to her schooling and routines.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635 (1999).support_reasoning: The case concerns post-divorce modification of alimony and the effect of a merged separation agreement; it does not address parenting time, relocation, school-night travel burdens, or temporary orders regarding custody/visitation. Nothing in the opinion provides a legal standard or authority for modifying midweek overnights due to a parent’s relocation or impacts on a child’s schooling. Therefore it does not support the specific parenting-time proposition cited.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635 (1999).relevant_excerpt: "A party seeking to modify a judgment for alimony or child support 'must demonstrate a material change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.' Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), citing Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). 'In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances' (emphasis added). Schuler v. Schuler, supra at 370."
